feature_title: Change of a to o before labialized stops
feature_description: In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have an a > o / _[+cons, +round] phonetic alternation or sound change. By this rule, /a/ is rounded before a labialized consonant. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two Kina word forms (which find a cognate in most dialects): /ʁagʷas/ 'to see' and /maɢːʷal/ 'nettle'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable and one the consonantal segment after it. In final values, values aw / äCʷ / eCʷ / and absence (-) are grouped together as not matching the sample, marked as NA, values agʷ / aɢʷ / aɢːʷ / aqʷ are grouped together as having the sound [a], and values ogʷ / oɢʷ as having [o]. It's important to note that I don't know enough to interpret the phonological nature of the combinations. I consider only labialization on a surface level: regardless of whether it is intrinsic or due to proximity to a rounded vowel. Same applies for o ~ a: we can't assume whether the distinction has been phonologised or it is a surface-level alternation.

feature_title: Change of a to o before labialized stops
feature_description: In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have an a > o / _[+cons, +round] phonetic alternation or sound change. By this rule, /a/ is rounded before a labialized consonant. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two Kina word forms (which find a cognate in most dialects): /ʁagʷas/ 'to see' and /maɢːʷal/ 'nettle'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable and one the consonantal segment after it. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable and one the consonantal segment after it. In final values, values aw / äCʷ / eCʷ / and absence (-) are grouped together as not matching the sample, marked as NA, values agʷ / aɢʷ / aɢːʷ / aqʷ are grouped together as having the sound [a], and values ogʷ / oɢʷ as having [o]. It's important to note that I don't know enough to interpret the phonological nature of the combinations. I consider only labialization on a surface level: regardless of whether it is intrinsic or due to proximity to a rounded vowel. Same applies for o ~ a: we can't assume whether the distinction has been phonologised or it is a surface-level alternation.

feature_title: Change of a to o before w
feature_description: In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have an a > o / _w phonetic alternation or sound change. By this rule, /a/ is rounded before a voiced labial approximant (or whatever its realisation is in a given utterance). In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two inter-dialectal lexemes: /ɢaw/ 'ceiling' and /awʁu/ 'poison'. For a number of dialects we also asked for the words /awči/ 'hunter' and /sawχura/ 'sleeps(III, PRS)' (as in 'The cow is sleeping'). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable before /w/. In this feature, ɨ and ə values of the correspondent vowel in these words are considered, because it is a freqent correspondence, even though it doesn't fall under the generalization of presence or abscence of a > o change. Final values are a, o and oː (from monophtongisation of ow), ɨ / ə (as non-low mid vowels), NA (when the congate wasn't attested or when it was attested, but with aː / äw / a, bleeding the a > o change).

feature_description: In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have an a > o / _w phonetic alternation or sound change. By this rule, /a/ is rounded before a voiced labial approximant (or whatever its realisation is in a given utterance). In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two inter-dialectal lexemes: /ɢaw/ 'ceiling' and /awʁu/ 'poison'. For a number of dialects we also asked for the words /awči/ 'hunter' and /sawχura/ 'sleeps(III, PRS)' (as in 'The cow is sleeping'). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable before /w/. In this feature, ɨ and ə values of the correspondent vowel in these words are considered, because it is a freqent correspondence, even though it doesn't fall under the generalization of presence or abscence of a > o change. Final values are a, o and oː (from monophtongisation of ow), ɨ / ə (as non-low mid vowels), NA (when the congate wasn't attested or when it was attested, but with aː / äw / a, bleeding the a > o change).

feature_title: fronting of u to ü in plural verbal stems
feature_description: <Rutul stems inflect for number in periphrastic verb forms.> Verbal number interacts with animacy <of the subject>, which sometimes allows us to contrast human plural (HPL) and animal/inanimate (NPL) plural forms of the verb. Some verbs with the root vowel /u/ undergo fronting of the stem in plural, i.e. alternation u ~ ü. In Kina, this applies to both HPL and NPL stems. [Danielms] However, the set of verbs accessible to fronting, and whether the fronting happens in NPL, varies across dialects. In this feature, we diagnose this by eliciting two verbs hulqas 'to play' and ʁurʁas 'to stroll', in prototypical SG, NPL and HPL contexts (in periphrastic past). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable. In final values, values u / uˁ are grouped together as [-front], and values ü / üˁ are grouped together as [+front].

[Danielms] However, the set of verbs accessible to fronting, and whether the fronting happens in NPL, varies across dialects. In this feature, we diagnose this by eliciting two verbs hulqas 'to play' and ʁurʁas 'to stroll', in prototypical SG, NPL and HPL contexts (in periphrastic past). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable. In final values, values u / uˁ are grouped together as [-front], and values ü / üˁ are grouped together as [+front].

Some verbs with the root vowel /u/ undergo fronting of the stem in plural, i.e. alternation u ~ ü. In Kina, this applies to both HPL and NPL stems. [Danielms] However, the set of verbs accessible to fronting, and whether the fronting happens in NPL, varies across dialects. In this feature, we diagnose this by eliciting two verbs hulqas 'to play' and ʁurʁas 'to stroll', in prototypical SG, NPL and HPL contexts (in periphrastic past). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the vowels in the first syllable. In final values, values u / uˁ are grouped together as [-front], and values ü / üˁ are grouped together as [+front].

In a simple rule, some dialects are expected to have a [+velar, +high, -back, -cont, +voice, -son] > [+cont] / _# phonetic alternation. By this rule we expect lenition of word-final /g/ and /gʲ/ to /ɣ/ and /ɣʲ/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for a cognate realisations of two inter-dialectal lexemes /ɢarg/ 'male sheep' and /uˁrdegʲ/ 'wild duck'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the finals of two words. In final values, values g / gʲ are grouped together as [-cont], and values ɣ / ɣʲ / j are grouped together as [+cont]. The value [j] is expected, because my ear cannot always distinguish between it and a fronted velar [ɣʲ], which is expected on structural level.

feature_title: Loanword f adopted as labialized x
feature_description: Many Nakh-Daghestan languages lack /f/ in their phonemic inventories. [Chirikba 2008: 50] When borrowing a loanword with /f/, like Azeri tüfängʲ 'rifle' or Arabic fikr 'thought', loan /f/ is usually rendered as /p/ or /b/ (see St. Dargwa tupang, pikri). Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.
stimuli: "acclamation, respect, what you say when an older person sared a decent thought" //aːferin//

Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.
stimuli: "acclamation, respect, what you say when an older person sared a decent thought" //aːferin//

[Chirikba 2008: 50] When borrowing a loanword with /f/, like Azeri tüfängʲ 'rifle' or Arabic fikr 'thought', loan /f/ is usually rendered as /p/ or /b/ (see St. Dargwa tupang, pikri). Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.

Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.

This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.
stimuli: "a small nut that grows wild in a forest, hazelnut" //Findɨqʼ//

Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.

Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.

Likewise, for Rutul, Ibragimov (2004: 32) reports that in most dialects /f/ is imported as /xʷ/ (which is acoutically similar and native to Rutul) or /p/: "xʷatima < Ar. faːtˁima, pindiqʼ < Az. fındıq". This paticular feature indicates whether /xʷ/ can appear instead of the loanword /f/. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for inter-dialectal lexemes that supposedly have arabic-turkic-persian origin, containing sound /f/ in source languages. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds occuring in place of /f/ in words /aːferin/ 'acclamation, respect', /kef/ 'pleasure, relax, keif', /findɨqʼ/ 'hazlenut', /χˁafte/ 'a week', /χilaf/ 'lie, tratory'. In final values, sounds like [xʷ] or [ф] would be labelled as <yes> (e.g. source /f/ underwent adaptation), [f] is labelled as <no> (no adaptation), and when both sounds occured (e.g. maybe they are not contrastive) I used the label <variation>.

A sound like /ö/, namely a mid front or central rounded vowel, appears in the inventories across dialects contigently. A particular potential source for it are Azeri loawords with /ö/. In most instances, Azeri /ö/ is rendered as /e/. Here we measure the geographic determinant of retaining the /ö/ by asking for cognates of the inter-dialectal lexeme /güzge/ 'mirror' (cf. Az. güzgü). The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final vowels. The values are ä / e for adaptation with /e/ and ö for retaining /ö/. Most importantly, we don't characterize this distinction as always phonological. Among some speakers both values were interchangeable. Among others [ö] appeared in first response or fast speech but when asked to name what sound there is or in careful speech [e] occured. Also worth mentioning that if /ü/ was adopted as /u/ in the first syllable, /ö/ always was adopted as /e/ in the second syllable.

Most importantly, we don't characterize this distinction as always phonological. Among some speakers both values were interchangeable. Among others [ö] appeared in first response or fast speech but when asked to name what sound there is or in careful speech [e] occured. Also worth mentioning that if /ü/ was adopted as /u/ in the first syllable, /ö/ always was adopted as /e/ in the second syllable.

Umlautization of the stem, e.g. applying the [+front, -back] features to the stem vowels, as a means of marking the PL forms appears not only in verbal stems (see phonology feature 14). Something of similar nature is found in paradigm of the lexeme /šu/ 'brother' and a few other kin terms in some dialects. While the regular formation would be adding a -bɨr/-mar suffix, actually the suffix -bä (-be, bäˁ, ba^) is added. Moreover, the noun has a special plural stem /šü/. [@filatovms §8.1] This feature indicates whether the stem paradigm levells (and by plural or by singular form) or the alternation remains. Preliminary values are vowels in the first syllable of brother.SG and the vowels of the first syllabe of brother.PL. The values ü / üˁ are grouped as PL-like, values u / uˁ are grouped as SG-like. Cases where 'brother' forms plural regulary are marked as not applicable.

[@filatovms §8.1] This feature indicates whether the stem paradigm levells (and by plural or by singular form) or the alternation remains. Preliminary values are vowels in the first syllable of brother.SG and the vowels of the first syllabe of brother.PL. The values ü / üˁ are grouped as PL-like, values u / uˁ are grouped as SG-like. Cases where 'brother' forms plural regulary are marked as not applicable.

/ɣ/ is tought of as a rare phoneme, cross-linguistically in Daghestan and in Rutul [no sources yet], and thus ɨ expect that it tends to change into other sounds. In Rutul, /ɣ/ in some dialects in some morphs can correspond to other similar sounds in other dialects. This feature tests possible reflexes of historical *ɣ in a given dialect. Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.

In Rutul, /ɣ/ in some dialects in some morphs can correspond to other similar sounds in other dialects. This feature tests possible reflexes of historical *ɣ in a given dialect. Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.
stimuli: "mutton stomach, what is used as cheese sourdough" //Ɣɨrɨɣ//

Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.

[@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.

In Rutul, /ɣ/ in some dialects in some morphs can correspond to other similar sounds in other dialects. This feature tests possible reflexes of historical *ɣ in a given dialect. Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.
stimuli: "a certain unpleasant taste (then asking for clarification: tasting musty / bitter / salty / having stale taste / bitter pepper" //Ɣɨrɣɨm(a)dɨ//

Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.

In Rutul, /ɣ/ in some dialects in some morphs can correspond to other similar sounds in other dialects. This feature tests possible reflexes of historical *ɣ in a given dialect. Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.
stimuli: "wild oat, a grass or grain to give to cows and sheep" //Ɣarɣal|r//

Mainly the options are /j, x, ɣ, g, w, ʁ/. The context of these changes is not entirely clear, but presumably involves palatalisation, labialization and changes in word onsets. [@ibragimov2004] To test these changes, we took the lexemes with the following sounds that are reported to have the correspondences to /ɣ/ in other dialects, and also some random lexemes with /ɣ/ in Kina for control: /ɣarɣal/ 'wild oat, oat', /ɣɨrɣɨmdɨ/ 'with a certain pungent, unpleasant taste', /ɣɨrɨɣ/ 'lamb stomach (used for cheese fermentation)', /rabɣantʼej/ 'firefly', /wirɨɣ/ 'sun', /wɨɣɨl/ 'husband', /ɣar/ 'snake'. Here, the vaules are the sounds in place of the first *ɣ.
stimuli: "firefly, the animal that lights up at night" //rabƔantʼej//

feature_description: Reconstructed proto Rutul *a gave a lot of possible reflexes across modern dialects. According to the common assumption, different palatalisation of the neighbouring vowels resulted in different reflexes. Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

Roughly, *CʲaC gave fronted ä and e, and reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. (Please correct me, I'm talking about a rough tendency here). This is an 'umbrella-feature', documenting many inter-dialectal roots that potentially have a reflex of *a. It is meant not to check which varieties underwent a particular sound change, but to see, which groupings naturally occur on a random arbitrary set of roots. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the first vowels in cognates of Kina words /bel/ 'forehead', /hejeg/ 'pot',  /ǯad/ 'forge', /kʼatʼ/ 'chicken', xed 'water', /čʼar/ 'a hair', /ekul/ 'nest' and /netʼ/ 'nit'. In this feature, the values ɜ / ɞ / o / ö are grouped together as realizations of /â/ (on this variation, see feature â > ö / _Cʷ), other values are presented as they are.

feature_title: Rounding of â before labialized stops
feature_description: A sound like /ö/, namely a mid front or central rounded vowel, appears in the inventories across dialects contigently. A particular potential source for it is a realization of phoneme /â/ before a labialized consonant. Overall, reconstruted a in *CaCʲ, which we denote by /â/, can realize in a variety of centralized vowels, like ɜ, ɞ, o, ö, ɨ, aˁ, ä and a. Here we measure all the possible inter-dialectal correspondences between the first vowel in cognates of Rutul /ekul/ 'nest'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the last vowels. In this feature, ä / e / aˁ / ɜ are grouped together as e-like (I noticed ɜ as a correspondence of â in some dialects) and values ö / o / ɞ are grouped as ö-like.

feature_title: Sound f from reconstructed labialized x
feature_description: Generally, labialization on velar fricatives has a tendency to fall off and be infequent across dialects. With regards to *xʷ, labialization is neutralized in several ways: it can simply disappear, for example, in word-final position; it can change the [round] feature of neighbouring vowels, if they are [+high, -low] (in this scenario /x/ still remains labialized on the surface level), or, finally, it can change the /x/ to /f/ or /ф/. This paticular feature describes the presence ot abcence of the latter change (xʷ > f). I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

This paticular feature describes the presence ot abcence of the latter change (xʷ > f). I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

With regards to *xʷ, labialization is neutralized in several ways: it can simply disappear, for example, in word-final position; it can change the [round] feature of neighbouring vowels, if they are [+high, -low] (in this scenario /x/ still remains labialized on the surface level), or, finally, it can change the /x/ to /f/ or /ф/. This paticular feature describes the presence ot abcence of the latter change (xʷ > f). I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. To avoid the outcomes being informed by inaccurate generalizations, I test multiple inter-dialectal words where *xʷ occurs in different contexts: word-finally and word-initially, before low and before high vowels, before rounded and unrounded vowels. In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of a number of lexemes with the sound xʷ appearing on surface level in diaclects that reliably didn't undergo the xʷ > f change. These are /kʼuxʲ ~ kʼuf/ 'beak', /maxʷ ~ maf/ 'light spring rain, fog', /uxun ~ ufun/ 'stomach', /xul ~ fɨl/ 'mold', /paxʷ ~ paf/ 'pufball mushroom', /xʷam ~ fam/ 'den', /čalaxʷ ~ čalaf/ 'honeycomb, bark, woodchips'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.
stimuli: "mushroom (that you pop); dust on the field" //paF//

feature_title: Sound f from reconstructed labialized x
feature_description: Generally, labialization on velar fricatives has a tendency to fall off and be infequent across dialects. I suppose, that the conditions where it happened vary, for example, it often doesn't happen when [xʷ] occurs next to /u/; social variation, lexical variation and free distribution between xʷ and f are also found. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the sounds in place of *xʷ plus their neigboring vowels, if the [round] occurs on them too. In final values, values xʷ / xu / ux are grouped together as [xʷ], and values f / uf / fu are grouped together as [f]. Values kʷ / šʷ / h / x that occured occasionally are marked as not applicable. Note that the feature is formulated in a way that doesn't assume the phonological status of f and xʷ, we only look at what allophones occur in certain historical positions.

In some dialects, reportedly, using fricative /ž/, not the affricate /ǯ/, is obligatory in at least one lexeme, and thus the contrast between /ž/ and /ǯ/ is thougt of as phonemic. [@ibragimov2004, @ibragimova2009, @danielvilatovms] In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two inter-dialectal lexemes: /maǯ/ 'a thorny plant (Gundelia tournefortii?)' and /garǯ/ 'rushlight; clove of garlic, resin'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final consonants. Final values are ž for fricative and ǯ for affricate. In dialects with phonemic /ž/ it is also expected to appear in some short words, in which it may not correspond to /ǯ/. For that see features [@pronouns]).
stimuli: "rushlight, something that you used for lighting up" //garŽ//

feature_description: In some dialects, reportedly, using fricative /ž/, not the affricate /ǯ/, is obligatory in at least one lexeme, and thus the contrast between /ž/ and /ǯ/ is thougt of as phonemic. [@ibragimov2004, @ibragimova2009, @danielvilatovms] In practice, we diagnose this by asking for cognates of two inter-dialectal lexemes: /maǯ/ 'a thorny plant (Gundelia tournefortii?)' and /garǯ/ 'rushlight; clove of garlic, resin'. The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final consonants. Final values are ž for fricative and ǯ for affricate. In dialects with phonemic /ž/ it is also expected to appear in some short words, in which it may not correspond to /ǯ/. For that see features [@pronouns]).
stimuli: "a thorny weed, the one that was used for feeding animals in the old days" //maŽ//

The sounds in check (preliminary values) are the final consonants. Final values are ž for fricative and ǯ for affricate. In dialects with phonemic /ž/ it is also expected to appear in some short words, in which it may not correspond to /ǯ/. For that see features [@pronouns]).
stimuli: "a thorny weed, the one that was used for feeding animals in the old days" //maŽ//

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa. ust'ulaχda geˁt gi. masalɨχda šikɨl qu (висит) / masalɨk šikil ki (припечатан, нарисован). χɨnχɨd χɨle eč χa. χaldɨ jiq'aχda maddɨ χal qu (сзади стоит) / gi (именно стоит, на основании)

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁana jiʔi/ʁa. ust'ulad q'anaχda getʲ/bisi gina wiʔi/gi. masɨlɨk kartina kina wiʔi/ki. gadɨjed χile eč χа. χaldɨ quna χal gi/qu

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: isk'amaj kitab ʁanaj. isk'amaχda get ginuw. masalɨk šikɨl kinuw. χɨnχɨdda eč fanuw. χaldɨ jiq'aχdɨ madɨdga χal jiʔi/qunuj

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa. ust'ulad q'anexde get gina wiʔi/gi. masalɨxde kartinka kina wiʔi/ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč χа. χalda jiq'aχda maddɨ χal gi/qu

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula uː kitab ʁa. ust'ulaχda get gini wiʔi/gi. masalɨk šikɨl ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč χа. χaldi jiq'aχda maddɨ χal jiʔi/qu

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula ʁanij / ok ʁa kitab. ust'ulaχda ginuw get / ok gi. masalak kinuw šikɨl / ok ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč χa / χanuw. χaldɨ jiq'aχda mattɨ χal qu / ok qunij

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa. ust'ula q'aneχda get gi. masalɨχda šikil qu/ki ok. χɨnχɨd χile eč χа. χaldɨ quna gene χal gi/qu ok/quj

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa. ust'ulad q'anixde (q'anašde) gaˁt gina wiʔi. masalɨxʲde šikil ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč χana wiʔi. χaldɨ jiq'aχda maddɨ χal ʁa // ok qu / quna jiʔi

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa. ust'ulad q'aneχda get gina wi/gi. masalɨχda kartina/šikilʲ qu. gadɨjed χile eč χа. χaldɨ quna gene χal qu/ki

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula kitab ʁa/ʁanaj. ust'ulaχda get gi/ginaw. maslakʲ šikɨl ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč xʷа/xʷаnaw. χaldi jiq'aχda maddɨ χal qu/qunaj

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: stola uː kitab ʁa/ʁana ji/ʁanaj. stolaχda aw wiʔi (orː gi) get. masalɨk kina wi šikɨl//masalɨkla saʔ kinaw (or: sawχɨr a) šikɨl. χɨnχɨd χile xʷаnaw/xʷa eč. χaldɨ quʔ na jiʔi maddɨ χal

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula ʁani jiʔi/ʁa kitab. ust'ulad q'anaxʲda gina wiʔi/gi gaˁt . masalɨχda quni wiʔi/qu/quj šikilʲ. χɨnχɨd χile eč χаj/χa. χaldi jiˁq'aχda maddɨ χal qu

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs

answer: isk'ama uː kitab ʁanaji/ʁa. isk'amad q'aneχda get ginawi/gi. maslɨk kinawi/ki šikɨl . χɨnχɨd χɨle eč xʷаnawi/xʷa. išdɨ χaldɨ jiq'aχda maddɨ χal qu/jiʔi/qunaji

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula/stola kitab ʁa/ʁana ji. ust'ulaχda/stolaχda get wiʔi/gi/gina wi. masalɨk kina wi kartinka/masalɨk kartinka ki. χɨnχɨd χile eč χʷа. jiq'aχda maddɨ χalxa jiʔi/qu

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: isk'ama kitab ʁa. isk'amad q'anʲakʲ gʲat gi/gini wiʔi. masalɨk šikɨl ki. χɨnχɨd χɨle eč χа. ust'ula ʁa kitab // ok ʁaniʔ

feature_description: Inventory of locative stative verbs
stimuli: На столе есть книга. Под столом есть кошка. На стене есть картина. У мальчика в руках яблоко. Сзади дома ещё дом стоит.
answer: ust'ula ʁa kitab // ok ʁaniʔ. ust'ulaχda gi get // ok gini wiʔ. masalɨkʲ kini wiʔ šɨkɨl // ok ki. χɨnχɨd χile χa eč // χani wiʔ. χaldɨ jiq'aχda maddɨ χal jiʔ / jiʔi // giniʔ // ok qu / quniʔ

answer: ust'ula uː ʁa kitab. ust'ulad q'aneχda gi gaˁt. masalɨχla saʔ qu šikil / masalɨkʲ ki šikil (drawing on the wall). gadijed χɨle χa eč. χaldɨ jiq'aχda maddɨ χalbɨr gi

In the short form of the past tense, the stative verbs are marked with the past tense suffix -j in the majority of varieties (e.g. a-j ‘was not there’). In the long form of the past tense, the past tense of the copula is employed, cf. ani jiʔi-j in Kina or ana i-na in Khnov.
stimuli: Мой отец был дома. Моя машина была во дворе.

feature_title: Stative verb “be”, present tense, long form
feature_description: Stative verbs can have a short form and a long form of the present tense. The long form is periphrastic and consists of the converbial form of the stative and the present-tense copula. Both the long form and the short form of the copula can occur in such periphrastic constructions (e.g. a-ni jiʔi vs. a-ni i ‘IN.be 1.COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < *a-na w-i ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). The maps below show the distribution of the long present tense forms.
answer: izdɨ did χal a/ aniʔ / *ani jiʔi

feature_description: Stative verbs can have a short form and a long form of the present tense. The long form is periphrastic and consists of the converbial form of the stative and the present-tense copula. Both the long form and the short form of the copula can occur in such periphrastic constructions (e.g. a-ni jiʔi vs. a-ni i ‘IN.be 1.COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < *a-na w-i ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). The maps below show the distribution of the long present tense forms.
stimuli: Если в предложении "Наш дом в центре села." сказали короткую форму типа "а", спросить, можно ли сказать длинную типа "ани и"/"ани йи". Если сказали длинную форму типа "ани и"/"ани йи", спросить, можно ли сказать короткую форму типа "а".
answer: išdɨ χal muɢuˁd jiq'dɨχuda a // anɨj (better) / ginij anɨj

Both the long form and the short form of the copula can occur in such periphrastic constructions (e.g. a-ni jiʔi vs. a-ni i ‘IN.be 1.COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < *a-na w-i ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). The maps below show the distribution of the long present tense forms.

feature_title: Stative verb “be”, present tense, short form
feature_description: Stative verbs can have a short form and a long form of the present tense. The short form is synthetic and monosyllabic, with the root -a or -i and a locative prefix (e.g. a < ʔa ‘IN.be’). The long form is periphrastic and consists of the converbial form of the stative and the present-tense copula (e.g. a-ni w-iʔi ‘IN.be 3-COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < *a-na w-i ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). In some varieties, only the long or only the short present tense occurs in the stimuli sentences. The maps below show the distribution of the short present tense forms. Our stimuli sentences mainly described a general location in side (e.g. in a house), hence the verb a 'IN.be' is mostly used. In some stimuli sentences, however, the speakers suggested another stative verb gi 'SUB.be', which describes another spatial configuration but has the same inflection. On the map, the distribution for both verbs is shown. For simplicity, the value description only mentions the verb a.
stimuli: Мой отец дома. Моя машина во дворе.
answer: izdɨ did χal a. izdɨ mašin šeri gi / gini wi.

feature_description: Stative verbs can have a short form and a long form of the present tense. The short form is synthetic and monosyllabic, with the root -a or -i and a locative prefix (e.g. a < ʔa ‘IN.be’). The long form is periphrastic and consists of the converbial form of the stative and the present-tense copula (e.g. a-ni w-iʔi ‘IN.be 3-COP’ in Kina). In some varieties, the long form is contracted, with the copula becoming suffixed to the stative verb (e.g. a-na-w ‘IN.be-3’ < *a-na w-i ‘IN.be-CVB 3-COP’ in Shinaz). In some varieties, only the long or only the short present tense occurs in the stimuli sentences. The maps below show the distribution of the short present tense forms. Our stimuli sentences mainly described a general location in side (e.g. in a house), hence the verb a 'IN.be' is mostly used. In some stimuli sentences, however, the speakers suggested another stative verb gi 'SUB.be', which describes another spatial configuration but has the same inflection. On the map, the distribution for both verbs is shown. For simplicity, the value description only mentions the verb a.
stimuli: Мой отец дома. Моя машина во дворе.
answer: izdɨ did χala a. izdɨ mašin šehridɨ ʁa / a // ɢapɨxde / ɢapɨšde gi.

feature_description: Intransitive verbs can form causatives in several different ways. The most frequent one is to combine a special form of the main verb with the verb hɨʔɨr (‘do’, dialect of Rutul). Another way is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). Much more rarely, the verbs ʁaʁur (‘force’), sigɨr (‘send’), χar hɨʔɨr (‘force do’) or wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

The most frequent one is to combine a special form of the main verb with the verb hɨʔɨr (‘do’, dialect of Rutul). Another way is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). Much more rarely, the verbs ʁaʁur (‘force’), sigɨr (‘send’), χar hɨʔɨr (‘force do’) or wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

Counterfactual conditional converbs are used in clauses subordinate to main clauses with counterfactual meaning, such as ‘If he hadn't died, he would be with us now’. The following suffixes have been attested in counterfactual converbs: -ni, -nij, -jdi, -jde, -jden, -jdena, -jdene, -jdin, -jdini, -jdijni, -dejni, -dini.
stimuli: Если бы он не умер, он был бы сейчас с нами.
answer: hawadɨ jiq'ɨ dišdejni, bɨsda jaqmɨfã inadi

feature_title: Differentiation of the optative and the jussive
feature_description: The jussive (or 3rd person imperative) can be expressed by the same form as the optative (expression of blessings and curses). In other words, this feature answers the question whether the same form is used in the sentences ‘Let your parents come to school’ and ‘May Allah help you’.

Hortative (or 1st person plural imperative) conveys an invitation to a joint action. Hortatives can be expressed by a combination of the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or a special particle (HORT.PTCL) with the infinitive of the main verb. In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used as a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used as a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

Hortative (or 1st person plural imperative) conveys an invitation to a joint action. Hortatives can be expressed by a combination of the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or a special particle (HORT.PTCL) with the infinitive of the main verb. In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used as a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).
answer: dɨq' luwk hawas mid χuk / dɨq' sibk'as mid χuq

In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used as a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

feature_description: The perfective stem of the verb ‘do’ can contain an ejective uvular root consonant - haq'ɨr. In most dialects, however, this consonant has changed into a glottal stop.

Universal concessive conditional converbs are used in subordinate clauses in such sentences as ‘Wherever you go, I'll go with you’. This converb can be marked by a suffix or by a combination of a suffix and an additive particle. Note that only the use of the additive particle on the converb itself was mapped. In some cases, the additive particle can be placed in a different position in the clause; in this case, its presence is not reflected on the map.
stimuli: Куда бы ты ни пошел, я с тобой пойду
answer: hila ʁu hɨxɨdde, zɨ jiqasɨ waxʷana

feature_description: Universal concessive conditional converbs are used in subordinate clauses in such sentences as ‘Wherever you go, I'll go with you’. This converb can be marked by a suffix or by a combination of a suffix and an additive particle. Note that only the use of the additive particle on the converb itself was mapped. In some cases, the additive particle can be placed in a different position in the clause; in this case, its presence is not reflected on the map.
stimuli: Что бы я ему ни давала, он ничего не ест
answer: zɨ hanas šiw wɨdde, hana šešun ɨler ǯʲiš

In some cases, the additive particle can be placed in a different position in the clause; in this case, its presence is not reflected on the map.
stimuli: Куда бы ты ни пошел, я с тобой пойду
answer: wɨ hile hɨxɨdixa, zɨ waxʷan((x)a) jiq'asdɨ

Personal elative (going from X's place) can be marked by spatial forms  -χdaː ; -qla / -χla  'POST/SUB ELATIVE' or -kla / -klʲa  'INTER/CONT ELATIVE' or by means of postpositional phrase -d ǯigijaː (-d ǯigijaːla) 'from X's place'. In Shinaz for some speakers it is possible to employ ǯigijaː without dependent attributive marker -dɨ.
